Enhancing Privacy in Federated Learning
through Local Training

Nicola Bastianello, Changxin Liu, Karl H. Johansson The authors are with the School of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, and Digital Futures, KTH Royal Institute of Technology, Sweden. { nicolba | changxin | kallej }@kth.se.This work was partially supported by the European Union‚Äôs Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under grant agreement No. 101070162, partially by the Swedish Research Council Distinguished Professor Grant 2017-01078, Knut and Alice Wallenberg Foundation Wallenberg Scholar Grant, and partially by the NSERC Postdoctoral Fellowship PDF-577876-2023.
Abstract

In this paper we propose the federated private local training algorithm (Fed-PLT) for federated learning, to overcome the challenges of (i) expensive communications and (ii) privacy preservation. We address (i) by allowing for both partial participation and local training, which significantly reduce the number of communication rounds between the central coordinator and computing agents. The algorithm matches the state of the art in the sense that the use of local training demonstrably does not impact accuracy. Additionally, agents have the flexibility to choose from various local training solvers, such as (stochastic) gradient descent and accelerated gradient descent. Further, we investigate how employing local training can enhance privacy, addressing point (ii). In particular, we derive differential privacy bounds and highlight their dependence on the number of local training epochs. We assess the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm by comparing it to alternative techniques, considering both theoretical analysis and numerical results from a classification task.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, privacy, local training, partial participation

I Introduction

Federated learning has proved to be a powerful framework to enable private cooperative learning [1, 2, 3]. Indeed, federated learning allows a set of agents to pool their resources together to train a more accurate model than any single agent could. This is accomplished by relying on a central coordinator that iteratively collects and aggregates locally trained models ‚Äì without the need to share raw data. Federated learning has been successfully deployed in different applications, including healthcare [4], wireless networks [5], mobile devices, Internet-of-Things, and sensor networks [6], power systems [7], and intelligent transportation [8], to name a few.

Clearly, all these applications may involve potentially sensitive and/or proprietary training data. Therefore, a fundamental challenge in the federated set-up is to guarantee the privacy of these data throughout the learning process. However, despite the fact that in a federated architecture the agents are not required to share raw data, various attacks have emerged to extract private information from the trained model or its predictions [9, 10, 11]. Thus, employing the federated learning architecture is not sufficient to ensure privacy, and tailored techniques need to be developed [12].

Besides privacy preservation, another fundamental challenge in federated learning is the expensiveness of communications. Indeed, the models exchanged by the agents are oftentimes high dimensional, especially when training (deep) neural networks [3], resulting in resource-intensive communications. Thus, one of the most important objectives is to design federated learning algorithms that employ as few communications as possible, while still guaranteeing good accuracy of the trained model. Different heuristics have been proposed to accomplish this objective, with the main ones arguably being partial participation111A.k.a. client selection. [13], local training [14], and quantization/compression [15]. In this paper we will focus on the former two, which we review in the following.

As the name suggests, when applying partial participation only a subset of the agents is selected at each iteration to communicate their local models to the coordinator. This allows to reduce the number of agent-coordinator communications required, at the cost of potentially slower convergence [13]. Local training proposes a complementary approach, by aiming to increase the time between communication rounds. The idea is for the agents to perform multiple epochs of local training (e.g. via stochastic gradient descent) for each round of communication. However, this may result in worse accuracy, especially due to the client drift phenomenon [14]. Indeed, locally trained models may be biased by the use of data that are not representative of the overall distribution, thus leading to a drift that cannot be corrected by the coordinator. In this paper we will therefore focus on designing a federated learning algorithm that allows for both partial participation and local training ‚Äì without compromising accuracy.

Summarizing the discussion above, the objective of this paper is two-fold. On the one hand, we are interested in designing a privacy-preserving federated learning algorithm. On the other hand, we require that such algorithm employs partial participation and local training to reduce the number of communications, but without affecting accuracy. The approach we propose to pursue these objectives is to leverage local training to enhance privacy, highlighting the synergy of communication reduction and privacy. In particular, we offer the following contributions:

  1. 1.

    We design a federated learning algorithm, abbreviated as Fed-PLT, based on the Peaceman-Rachford splitting method [16], which allows for both partial participation and local training. In particular, the algorithm allows for a subset of the agents to activate randomly at each iteration, and communicate the results of local training to the coordinator. The number of local training epochs is a tunable parameter of the algorithm. Moreover, the algorithm can be applied to both smooth and composite problems (with a smooth and non-smooth part).

  2. 2.

    We prove exact convergence (in mean) of Fed-PLT in strongly convex, composite scenarios when the agents use gradient descent during local training. This results shows that the use of local training does not give rise to the client drift phenomenon, and thus it does not degrade accuracy of the trained model. Additionally, we analyze Fed-PLT‚Äôs convergence when the agents employ accelerated gradient descent for local training, showing the flexibility of the proposed approach.

  3. 3.

    We further analyze the convergence of Fed-PLT when stochastic gradient descent or noisy gradient descent are used for local training. The result characterizes convergence to a neighborhood of the optimal solution which depends on the variance of the noise. We then highlight the privacy benefits of using local training with a noisy solver. In particular, we characterize the differential privacy of the disclosed final model, as a function of the number of local training epochs and the gradient noise.

  4. 4.

    We apply Fed-PLT for a logistic regression problem, and compare its performance with a number of state-of-the-art federated algorithm that employ local training. We observe that the convergence rate of the proposed algorithm, in this example, is smaller than all other alternatives. We then analyze Fed-PLT by discussing its performance for different values of the tunable parameters and number of agents. One interesting observation is that the convergence rate is not a monotonically decreasing function of the number of local epochs (as may be suggested by Fed-PLT‚Äôs foundation in the Peaceman-Rachford splitting). Rather, there exists an optimal, finite number of epochs.

I-A Related works

(Private) federated learning is an active and growing area of research, and providing a comprehensive overview of the literature is outside the scope of this paper. In the following, we provide a brief overview of privacy in federated learning, and discuss the state of the art in federated algorithms employing local training.

Different privacy techniques have been proposed, with the most studied being homomorphic encryption [17], secret-sharing protocol [18], and differential privacy (DP) [19]. The latter stands out as easier to implement as compared to the other two methodologies. This is indeed the case as in differential privacy the aim is to obscure local training data by introducing perturbations to the models shared by the agents. This is achieved by simply randomizing learning algorithms with additive noise (often following a normal or Laplace distribution). But despite the simplicity of such privacy mechanism, DP provides a solid framework that enables the derivation of theoretical privacy guarantees [20, 21]. We remark that recently, the use of random additive noise to improve privacy has also been complemented with other techniques such as quantization and compression of communications [22, 23, 24]. This is similar to the concept of employing local training to enhance privacy, as explored in this paper. Owing to its effectiveness, differential privacy has been fruitfully applied in diverse engineering fields, ranging from federated learning [3] and distributed optimization [25], to control system design [26], estimation [27], and consensus-seeking [28]. Thus we will follow these works in using DP throughout this paper.

We turn now to reviewing related works on federated learning with local training. In particular, we consider Fed-PD [29], FedLin [30], TAMUNA [31], LED [32], 5GCS [14]. Their comparison with the proposed Fed-PLT is summarized in Table¬†I.

Let us start by evaluating the memory footprint of the different algorithms. In Table¬†I we report the number of models that need to be stored by agents and coordinator in between communication rounds. As we can see, except for [14], all other methods ‚Äì including Fed-PLT‚Äì require the storage of 2‚ÄãN+12ùëÅ12N+1 variables, i.e. two models per agent and one at the coordinator.

Turning now to the local training, we can classify algorithms based on the solvers that can be applied by the agents. For [29, 30, 31, 32] only (stochastic) gradient descent is allowed, while Fed-PLT also allows for accelerated (S)GD and noisy GD (to enhance privacy). Only [14] potentially allows for a broader class of solvers, provided that they verify a specific descent inequality. Such inequality is verified by SGD and variance reduced SGD, but [14] does not evaluate if accelerated SGD verifies it. The compared algorithms also differ in the number of local training epochs that the agents can perform. On one side, we have [31] which implements local training by randomly choosing whether to perform a communication round at each gradient step. On the other we have [29, 30, 32, 14] and Fed-PLT, which apply a deterministic number of local epochs NesubscriptùëÅe{N_{\mathrm{e}}}. However, for [29, 14] convergence is guaranteed only if NesubscriptùëÅe{N_{\mathrm{e}}} is lower bounded by N¬Øesubscript¬ØùëÅe\underaccent{\bar}{N}_{\mathrm{e}}, which may be larger than 111.

Partial participation is allowed only in the proposed Fed-PLT and [31, 14], and not in [29, 30, 32]. Furthermore, only Fed-PLT includes a privacy preserving mechanism with a rigorous differential privacy guarantee (derived in section¬†VI). All the other methods do not evaluate the privacy perspective.

Finally, the algorithms also differ in the classes of problems for which a convergence guarantee can be derived. [29, 30, 32] present more general results for non-convex problems, while the assumption of strong convexity is required in the analysis of Fed-PLT and [31, 14]. However, Fed-PLT can be applied on composite problems, differently from all the other algorithms that are designed for smooth problems only.

II Preliminaries

II-A Operator theory

In the following we review some notions in operator theory 222Following the convention in the convex optimization literature, we use the term operator, even though in finite-dimensional spaces mapping would be more appropriate.; for a comprehensive background we refer to [16, 33]. The central goal in operator theory is to find the fixed points of a given operator.

II-B Application to convex optimization

Operator theory can be applied to solve convex optimization problems by reformulating them into fixed point problems. In the following we review two operator-based solvers that will be useful throughout the paper.

II-C Stochastic operator theory

In many learning applications the methods described in the previous section¬†II-B cannot be directly applied due to practical constraints. For example, the gradient descent of Lemma¬†2 may only have access to stochastic gradients [36]. And, in decentralized set-ups, asynchronous computations may result in only some of the components of \mathbold‚Äãx\mathboldùë•\mathbold{x} being updated at any given time [37]. In these scenarios, optimization algorithms are modeled by stochastic operators, which we briefly review in this section, see [38] and references therein.

where p¬Ø=mini‚Å°pi¬Øùëùsubscriptùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ\underaccent{\bar}{p}=\min_{i}p_{i}, p¬Ø=maxi‚Å°pi¬Øùëùsubscriptùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ\bar{p}=\max_{i}p_{i}, and Œ∂¬Ø=1‚àíp¬Ø+p¬Ø‚ÄãŒ∂2¬ØùúÅ1¬Øùëù¬ØùëùsuperscriptùúÅ2\bar{\zeta}=\sqrt{1-\underaccent{\bar}{p}+\underaccent{\bar}{p}\zeta^{2}}.

II-D Differential privacy

In this section we review some concepts in differential privacy. Let ùíü={Œæ1,‚Ä¶,Œæq}ùíüsuperscriptùúâ1‚Ä¶superscriptùúâùëû\mathcal{D}=\{\xi^{1},\dots,\xi^{q}\} denote a dataset of size qùëûq with records drawn from a universe ùïèùïè\mathbb{X}. Two datasets ùíüùíü\mathcal{D} and ùíü‚Ä≤superscriptùíü‚Ä≤\mathcal{D}^{\prime} are referred to as neighboring if they are of the same size and differ in at most one data point.

Definition 4 (R√©nyi differential privacy).

Given Œª>1ùúÜ1\lambda>1, a randomized mechanism ‚Ñ≥:ùïèq‚Üíùïê:‚Ñ≥‚Üísuperscriptùïèùëûùïê\mathcal{M}:\mathbb{X}^{q}\rightarrow\mathbb{Y} is said to have (Œª,Œµ)ùúÜùúÄ(\lambda,\varepsilon)-R√©nyi differential privacy (RDP) [39], if for every pair of neighboring datasets ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}, ùíü‚Ä≤‚ààùïèqsuperscriptùíü‚Ä≤superscriptùïèùëû\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{X}^{q}, we have

DŒª(‚Ñ≥(ùíü)||‚Ñ≥(ùíü‚Ä≤))‚â§Œµ,{\rm D}_{\lambda}(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})||\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime}))\leq\varepsilon,

where DŒª(‚Ñ≥(ùíü)||‚Ñ≥(ùíü‚Ä≤)){\rm D}_{\lambda}(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})||\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})) is the ŒªùúÜ\lambda-R√©nyi divergence between ‚Ñ≥‚Äã(ùíü)‚Ñ≥ùíü\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}) and ‚Ñ≥‚Äã(ùíü‚Ä≤)‚Ñ≥superscriptùíü‚Ä≤\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime}), i.e.,

DŒª(‚Ñ≥(ùíü)||‚Ñ≥(ùíü‚Ä≤))=1Œª‚àí1‚Äãlog‚Äã‚à´ùïê‚Ñô‚Äã[‚Ñ≥‚Äã(ùíü)=z]Œª‚Äã‚Ñô‚Äã[‚Ñ≥‚Äã(ùíü‚Ä≤)=z]1‚àíŒª‚Äãùëëz.\begin{split}&{\rm D}_{\lambda}(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})||\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime}))\\ &=\frac{1}{\lambda-1}\log\int_{\mathbb{Y}}\mathbb{P}[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})=z]^{\lambda}\mathbb{P}[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})=z]^{1-\lambda}dz.\end{split}

Another common notion in differential privacy is approximate differential privacy (ADP) [19]. In the following we introduce its definition and how RDP can be translated into ADP [39].

Definition 5 (Approximate differential privacy).

Given Œµ,Œ¥‚â•0ùúÄùõø0\varepsilon,\delta\geq 0, a randomized mechanism ‚Ñ≥:ùïèq‚Üíùïê:‚Ñ≥‚Üísuperscriptùïèùëûùïê\mathcal{M}:\mathbb{X}^{q}\rightarrow\mathbb{Y} is said to be (Œµ,Œ¥)ùúÄùõø(\varepsilon,\delta)-ADP, if for every pair of neighboring datasets ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}, ùíü‚Ä≤‚ààùïèqsuperscriptùíü‚Ä≤superscriptùïèùëû\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{X}^{q} and every subset ùí™‚äÜùïêùí™ùïê\mathcal{O}\subseteq\mathbb{Y}, we have

‚Ñô‚Äã[‚Ñ≥‚Äã(ùíü)‚ààùí™]‚â§eŒµ‚Äã‚Ñô‚Äã[‚Ñ≥‚Äã(ùíü‚Ä≤)‚ààùí™]+Œ¥.‚Ñôdelimited-[]‚Ñ≥ùíüùí™superscriptùëíùúÄ‚Ñôdelimited-[]‚Ñ≥superscriptùíü‚Ä≤ùí™ùõø\begin{split}\mathbb{P}[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})\in\mathcal{O}]\leq e^{\varepsilon}\mathbb{P}[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D^{\prime}})\in\mathcal{O}]+\delta.\end{split}
Lemma 5 (RDP to ADP conversion).

If a randomized algorithm is (Œª,ŒµùúÜùúÄ\lambda,\varepsilon)-RDP, then it is (Œµ+log‚Å°(1/Œ¥)Œª‚àí1,Œ¥)ùúÄ1ùõøùúÜ1ùõø(\varepsilon+\frac{\log(1/\delta)}{\lambda-1},\delta)-ADP, ‚àÄŒ¥‚àà(0,1)for-allùõø01\forall\delta\in(0,1).

III Problem Formulation

In the following we formally describe the problem at hand, and discuss the application-driven design objectives that the proposed algorithm should satisfy.

In principle,¬†eq.¬†7 could be now solved applying the Peaceman-Rachford splitting of¬†eq.¬†3, but due to practical constraints (discussed in section¬†III-B) this may not be possible. Instead, in section¬†IV we will show how to use PRS as a template to design a federated algorithm that can be applied in practice.

III-B Design objectives

In this section we discuss some of the challenges that arise in federated learning set-ups, due to the practical constraints that they pose [1, 3]. The objective in the remainder of the paper then is to design and analyze an algorithm that can provably overcome these challenges.

Communication burden

In machine learning we are often faced with the task of training high-dimensional models, with deep neural networks the foremost example. This implies that problem¬†eq.¬†5 may be characterized by n‚â´1much-greater-thanùëõ1n\gg 1. In a federated set-up then, sharing models between the agents and the coordinator imposes a significant communication burden [15]. Initial approaches to federated learning444Corresponding to the 1stsuperscript1st1^{\text{st}}‚Äì3rdsuperscript3rd3^{\text{rd}} generations in the categorization of [14]. therefore introduced different techniques to reduce the number of communications required, such as local training [3]. Local training requires that, before a round of communications, each agent perform multiple steps (or epochs) of minimization of the local loss function. Employing local training, however, may result in worse accuracy, especially when the loss functions of the agents are heterogeneous. The objective then is to design federated algorithms that perform local training without jeopardizing accuracy of the trained model, see e.g. [29, 30, 31, 14, 32].

Heterogeneous agents

The devices involved in the federated learning process may be in general very heterogeneous as regards to computational, storage, and communication capabilities. Indeed, these devices may be equipped with very different hardware (CPU, memory, battery), and they may be using different network connectivity (mobile or Wi-Fi) [1, 3]. The heterogeneity of the agents‚Äô resources implies that they may perform local computations, and transmit their results, at different rates. This results in partial participation, with only a subset of the agents being active at any given time. Besides arising from practical limitations, partial participation may also be enforced in order to relieve the communication burden. The goal therefore is to design a federated algorithm that allows for partial participation while preserving accuracy of the trained model.

Privacy

The leakage of private information through machine learning models‚Äô parameters and predictions has been extensively documented [9, 10, 11]. One notable example is the support vector machine (SVM) in its dual form, where the solution involves a linear combination of specific data points. Recently, there has been a growing interest in iterative randomized training algorithms that offer privacy-preserving guarantees [20, 21], such as RDP and ADP. However, the existing results suffer from privacy loss that increases over training epochs [40] and fail to support local training and the partial participation of heterogeneous agents [20]. These limitations make it challenging to extend those approaches to the specific setup addressed in this work. The objective of this study is to address these challenges by providing a rigorous privacy-preserving guarantee that remains bounded over time and is compatible with the federated learning setup under consideration.

To summarize, the goal of this paper is to design a federated algorithm with the following features:

  1. (i)

    Local training: the algorithm should allow for multiple epochs of local training, but without jeopardizing accuracy of the computed solution.

  2. (ii)

    Partial participation: the algorithm should allow for a subset of the agents to be active at any time, again without jeopardizing accuracy.

  3. (iii)

    Privacy: the algorithm should incorporate a privacy mechanism to safeguard the local training data.

IV Algorithm Design

In this section we derive and discuss the proposed Algorithm¬†1, highlighting the different design choices that it allows for.

IV-A Algorithm derivation

We start by applying the PRS of¬†eq.¬†3 to the federated optimization problem¬†eq.¬†7, which yields

\mathbold‚Äãyk+1\mathboldsubscriptùë¶ùëò1\displaystyle\mathbold{y}_{k+1} =proxœÅ‚Äãg‚Å°(\mathbold‚Äãzk)absentsubscriptproxùúåùëî\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò\displaystyle=\operatorname{prox}_{\rho g}(\mathbold{z}_{k}) (8a)
\mathbold‚Äãxk+1\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò1\displaystyle\mathbold{x}_{k+1} =proxœÅ‚Äãf‚Å°(2‚Äã\mathbold‚Äãyk+1‚àí\mathbold‚Äãzk)absentsubscriptproxùúåùëì2\mathboldsubscriptùë¶ùëò1\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò\displaystyle=\operatorname{prox}_{\rho f}(2\mathbold{y}_{k+1}-\mathbold{z}_{k}) (8b)
\mathbold‚Äãzk+1\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò1\displaystyle\mathbold{z}_{k+1} =\mathbold‚Äãzk+2‚Äã(\mathbold‚Äãxk+1‚àí\mathbold‚Äãyk+1),absent\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò2\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò1\mathboldsubscriptùë¶ùëò1\displaystyle=\mathbold{z}_{k}+2(\mathbold{x}_{k+1}-\mathbold{y}_{k+1}), (8c)

We now discuss the implementation of eq.¬†8a and eq.¬†8b in turn.

IV-A1 Implementation of¬†eq.¬†8a

More generally, one can apply any suitable local solver to compute¬†eq.¬†10, as discussed in section¬†IV-B. In particular, the choice of local solver can be leveraged to enhance privacy.

Finally, in the derivation above, each agent approximates its local proximal at each iteration k‚àà‚Ñïùëò‚Ñïk\in\mathbb{N}. However, this is not required, as Algorithm¬†1 allows for only a subset of active agents to share the results of their local training at iteration k‚àà‚Ñïùëò‚Ñïk\in\mathbb{N}; this feature is discussed in section¬†IV-C.

To summarize, the proposed Algorithm¬†1 provides two flexible design choices in the following key aspects:

  1. 1.

    local training: during local training, any suitable solver can be employed by the agents, including privacy preserving methods (objectives (i) and (iii));

  2. 2.

    partial participation: the algorithm allows for a subset of the agents to be active at any given time k‚àà‚Ñïùëò‚Ñïk\in\mathbb{N} (objective (ii)).

IV-B Local training methods

In principle, one may choose to use any suitable local solver to approximate the solution of minxi‚Å°di,k‚Äã(xi)=fi‚Äã(xi)+(1/2‚ÄãœÅ)‚Äã‚à•xi‚àívi,k‚à•2subscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùëëùëñùëòsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ12ùúåsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë£ùëñùëò2\min_{x_{i}}d_{i,k}(x_{i})=f_{i}(x_{i})+(1/2\rho)\left\lVert x_{i}-v_{i,k}\right\rVert^{2}. This problem is especially amenable since it is strongly convex, with di,k‚àà‚Ñ±Œª¬Ø+1/œÅ,Œª¬Ø+1/œÅ‚Äã(‚Ñùn)subscriptùëëùëñùëòsubscript‚Ñ±¬ØùúÜ1ùúå¬ØùúÜ1ùúåsuperscript‚Ñùùëõd_{i,k}\in\mathcal{F}_{{\underline{\lambda}}+1/\rho,{\bar{\lambda}}+1/\rho}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right). A first option is the gradient descent, already discussed in¬†eq.¬†11. Notice that by Lemma¬†2 we know that the gradient descent is contractive with rate œá=max‚Å°{|1‚àíŒ≥‚Äã(Œª¬Ø+1/œÅ)|,|1‚àíŒ≥‚Äã(Œª¬Ø+1/œÅ)|}ùúí1ùõæ¬ØùúÜ1ùúå1ùõæ¬ØùúÜ1ùúå\chi=\max\{|1-\gamma({\underline{\lambda}}+1/\rho)|,|1-\gamma({\bar{\lambda}}+1/\rho)|\}, which is minimized by choosing Œ≥=2/(Œª¬Ø+Œª¬Ø+2/œÅ)ùõæ2¬ØùúÜ¬ØùúÜ2ùúå\gamma=2/({\bar{\lambda}}+{\underline{\lambda}}+2/\rho). In the following, we discuss some alternatives that address different design objectives.

Accelerated gradient descent

Improving the performance of local training can be achieved by using the accelerated gradient descent, see e.g. [41, Algorithm¬†14], characterized by

wi,k0=xi,k,ui0=wi,k0ui‚Ñì+1=wi,k‚Ñì‚àí1Œª¬Ø‚Äã‚àádi,k‚Äã(wi,k‚Ñì)‚Ñì=0,‚Ä¶,Ne‚àí1wi,k‚Ñì+1=ui‚Ñì+1+Œª¬Ø‚àíŒª¬ØŒª¬Ø+Œª¬Ø‚Äã(ui‚Ñì+1‚àíui‚Ñì)xi,k+1=wi,kNe,formulae-sequenceformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñùëò0subscriptùë•ùëñùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëñ0superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñùëò0superscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëñ‚Ñì1superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñùëò‚Ñì1¬ØùúÜ‚àásubscriptùëëùëñùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñùëò‚Ñìformulae-sequence‚Ñì0‚Ä¶subscriptùëÅe1superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñùëò‚Ñì1superscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëñ‚Ñì1¬ØùúÜ¬ØùúÜ¬ØùúÜ¬ØùúÜsuperscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëñ‚Ñì1superscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëñ‚Ñìsubscriptùë•ùëñùëò1superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñùëòsubscriptùëÅe\begin{split}w_{i,k}^{0}&=x_{i,k},\ u_{i}^{0}=w_{i,k}^{0}\\ u_{i}^{\ell+1}&=w_{i,k}^{\ell}-\frac{1}{{\bar{\lambda}}}\nabla d_{i,k}(w_{i,k}^{\ell})\quad\ell=0,\ldots,{N_{\mathrm{e}}}-1\\ w_{i,k}^{\ell+1}&=u_{i}^{\ell+1}+\frac{\sqrt{{\bar{\lambda}}}-\sqrt{{\underline{\lambda}}}}{\sqrt{{\bar{\lambda}}}+\sqrt{{\underline{\lambda}}}}(u_{i}^{\ell+1}-u_{i}^{\ell})\\ x_{i,k+1}&=w_{i,k}^{N_{\mathrm{e}}},\end{split} (12)

which employs constant step-sizes owing to the strong convexity of di,ksubscriptùëëùëñùëòd_{i,k}. Local solvers with even better performance can also be chosen, for example (quasi-)Newton methods.

Stochastic gradient descent

Both gradient descent and accelerated gradient descent rely on the use of full gradient evaluations, which may be too computationally expensive in learning applications. Therefore, the agents may resort to stochastic gradient descent (SGD) methods [36], which employ approximated gradients during the local training. Recalling that the local costs are defined as fi‚Äã(x):=1q‚Äã‚àëj=1q‚Ñìi‚Äã(x;Œæi(j)),assignsubscriptùëìùëñùë•1ùëûsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëûsubscript‚Ñìùëñùë•superscriptsubscriptùúâùëñùëóf_{i}(x):=\frac{1}{q}\sum_{j=1}^{q}\ell_{i}(x;\xi_{i}^{(j)}), SGD makes use of the following approximate gradient

‚àá^‚Äãfi‚Äã(x)=1q‚Äã‚àëj‚àà‚Ñ¨‚àá‚Ñìi‚Äã(x;Œæi(j))^‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë•1ùëûsubscriptùëó‚Ñ¨‚àásubscript‚Ñìùëñùë•superscriptsubscriptùúâùëñùëó\hat{\nabla}f_{i}(x)=\frac{1}{q}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{B}}\nabla\ell_{i}(x;\xi_{i}^{(j)})

where ‚Ñ¨‚äÇ{1,‚Ä¶,q}‚Ñ¨1‚Ä¶ùëû\mathcal{B}\subset\{1,\ldots,q\} are the indices of a subset of data points chosen at random.

Private local training

The previous local solvers address performance concerns; however, when the design objective is privacy preservation, the agents should resort to the use of noisy gradient descent [20, 42]. In particular, the update of wi,k‚Ñì+1superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñùëò‚Ñì1w_{i,k}^{\ell+1} in¬†eq.¬†11 is perturbed with Gaussian noise:

wi,k‚Ñì+1=wi,k‚Ñì‚àíŒ≥‚Äã‚àádi,k‚Äã(wi,k‚Ñì)+ti,k‚Ñìti,k‚Ñì‚àº2‚ÄãŒ≥‚Äãùí©‚Äã(0,œÑ2‚ÄãIn)superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñùëò‚Ñì1superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñùëò‚Ñìùõæ‚àásubscriptùëëùëñùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñùëò‚Ñìsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëñùëò‚Ñìsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëñùëò‚Ñìsimilar-to2ùõæùí©0superscriptùúè2subscriptùêºùëõ\begin{split}w_{i,k}^{\ell+1}&=w_{i,k}^{\ell}-\gamma\nabla d_{i,k}(w_{i,k}^{\ell})+t_{i,k}^{\ell}\\ t_{i,k}^{\ell}&\sim\sqrt{2\gamma}\mathcal{N}(0,\tau^{2}{I}_{n})\end{split} (13)

where ‚Ñì=0,‚Ä¶,Ne‚àí1‚Ñì0‚Ä¶subscriptùëÅe1\ell=0,\ldots,{N_{\mathrm{e}}}-1, and œÑ2>0superscriptùúè20\tau^{2}>0 is the noise variance. The addition of a stochastic additive noise in each iteration of¬†eq.¬†13 allows us to establish rigorous differential privacy guarantees, which can be tuned by selecting the variance œÑ2superscriptùúè2\tau^{2}.

Remark 1 (Uncoordinated local solvers).

In this section we only discussed the case of ‚Äúcoordinated‚Äù local solvers777The terminology ‚Äúcoordinated‚Äù and ‚Äúuncoordinated‚Äù is borrowed from distributed optimization literature, see e.g. [43]., that is, all agents use the same solver with the same parameters (e.g. gradient with common ‚Äì or coordinated ‚Äì step-size Œ≥ùõæ\gamma). The results of section¬†V actually allow for uncoordinated solvers, with the agents either using different algorithms, or the same algorithm with different parameters. For example, if the local costs are such that fi‚àà‚Ñ±Œª¬Øi,Œª¬Øi‚Äã(‚Ñùn)subscriptùëìùëñsubscript‚Ñ±subscript¬ØùúÜùëñsubscript¬ØùúÜùëñsuperscript‚Ñùùëõf_{i}\in\mathcal{F}_{{\underline{\lambda}}_{i},{\bar{\lambda}}_{i}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right), then the local step-size can be tuned using the strong convexity and smoothness moduli of fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i}, instead of the global moduli Œª¬Ø=mini‚Å°Œª¬Øi¬ØùúÜsubscriptùëñsubscript¬ØùúÜùëñ{\underline{\lambda}}=\min_{i}{\underline{\lambda}}_{i}, Œª¬Ø=maxi‚Å°Œª¬Øi¬ØùúÜsubscriptùëñsubscript¬ØùúÜùëñ{\bar{\lambda}}=\max_{i}{\bar{\lambda}}_{i}. This is especially useful because it means that the algorithm can adapt to the heterogeneity of the local costs.

IV-C Partial participation

As discussed in section¬†III-B, there are different reasons why only a subset of the agents may participate at any given time k‚àà‚Ñïùëò‚Ñïk\in\mathbb{N}. On the one hand, the heterogeneity of the agents‚Äô hardware (CPU, battery, connectivity, ‚Ä¶) may result in different paces of local training. This means that not all agents will conclude their computations at the same time, and the coordinator will receive new results only from those that did. On the other hand, partial participation can be introduced by design in order to reduce the communication burden. In this case, the coordinator picks a (random) subset of the agents and requests that they send the new results of local training, thus reducing the number of communications exchanged. This scheme is often referred to as client selection [14].

The proposed Algorithm¬†1 allows for any partial participation, be it intrinsic (due to heterogeneity of the agents) or extrinsic (due to client selection). In particular, the only requirement, detailed in Assumption¬†2, is that at any given time an agent iùëñi participates in the learning with a given fixed probability pi‚àà(0,1]subscriptùëùùëñ01p_{i}\in(0,1].

V Convergence Analysis

In this section we prove the convergence of Algorithm¬†1. We start by showing that the proposed algorithm can be interpreted as a contractive operator. Then, building on this result we characterize convergence for the different local training choices discussed in section¬†IV-B.

V-A Contractiveness of Algorithm¬†1

The goal of this section is to show that Algorithm¬†1 can be characterized as a contractive operator, similarly to the PRS from which it was derived. First of all, we remark that yk+1subscriptùë¶ùëò1y_{k+1} only depends on \mathbold‚Äãzk\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò\mathbold{z}_{k}, and hence we can represent Algorithm¬†1 in terms of \mathbold‚Äãx\mathboldùë•\mathbold{x} and \mathbold‚Äãz\mathboldùëß\mathbold{z} only. In particular, letting ùí≥:‚Ñùn‚ÄãN√ó‚Ñùn‚ÄãN‚Üí‚Ñùn‚ÄãN:(\mathbold‚Äãxk,\mathbold‚Äãzk)‚Ü¶\mathbold‚Äãxk+1:ùí≥‚Üísuperscript‚ÑùùëõùëÅsuperscript‚ÑùùëõùëÅsuperscript‚ÑùùëõùëÅ:maps-to\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò1\mathcal{X}:\mathbb{R}^{nN}\times\mathbb{R}^{nN}\to\mathbb{R}^{nN}:(\mathbold{x}_{k},\mathbold{z}_{k})\mapsto\mathbold{x}_{k+1} be the map denoting the local updates, and assuming that all agents are active, we can write

[\mathbold‚Äãxk+1\mathbold‚Äãzk+1]=[ùí≥‚Äã(\mathbold‚Äãxk,\mathbold‚Äãzk)\mathbold‚Äãzk+2‚Äã(\mathbold‚Äãxk+1‚àíproxœÅ‚Äãg‚Å°(\mathbold‚Äãzk))]=ùíØ‚Äã[\mathbold‚Äãxk\mathbold‚Äãzk]matrix\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò1\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò1matrixùí≥\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò2\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò1subscriptproxùúåùëî\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëòùíØmatrix\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò\displaystyle\begin{bmatrix}\mathbold{x}_{k+1}\\ \mathbold{z}_{k+1}\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}\mathcal{X}(\mathbold{x}_{k},\mathbold{z}_{k})\\ \mathbold{z}_{k}+2(\mathbold{x}_{k+1}-\operatorname{prox}_{\rho g}(\mathbold{z}_{k}))\end{bmatrix}=\mathcal{T}\begin{bmatrix}\mathbold{x}_{k}\\ \mathbold{z}_{k}\end{bmatrix}

The following Proposition¬†1 proves that ùíØùíØ\mathcal{T} is contractive for a suitable choice of local solver.

Proposition 1 (Algorithm¬†1 is contractive).

Let the local solvers be œáNesuperscriptùúísubscriptùëÅe\chi^{N_{\mathrm{e}}}-contractive in the first argument, that is

‚à•ùí≥‚Äã(\mathbold‚Äãx,\mathbold‚Äãzk)‚àíùí≥‚Äã(\mathbold‚Äãy,\mathbold‚Äãzk)‚à•‚â§œáNe‚Äã‚à•\mathbold‚Äãx‚àí\mathbold‚Äãy‚à•,‚àÄ\mathbold‚Äãx,\mathbold‚Äãy‚àà‚Ñùn,formulae-sequencedelimited-‚à•‚à•ùí≥\mathboldùë•\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëòùí≥\mathboldùë¶\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëòsuperscriptùúísubscriptùëÅedelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldùë•\mathboldùë¶for-all\mathboldùë•\mathboldùë¶superscript‚Ñùùëõ\left\lVert\mathcal{X}(\mathbold{x},\mathbold{z}_{k})-\mathcal{X}(\mathbold{y},\mathbold{z}_{k})\right\rVert\leq\chi^{N_{\mathrm{e}}}\left\lVert\mathbold{x}-\mathbold{y}\right\rVert,\quad\forall\mathbold{x},\mathbold{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{n},

and let the PRS applied to¬†eq.¬†6 be Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta-contractive (cf. Lemma¬†3) with fixed point \mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø¬Ø\mathboldùëß\bar{\mathbold{z}}. Let the parameters œÅùúå\rho and NesubscriptùëÅe{N_{\mathrm{e}}} be chosen such that the following matrix is stable:

Then the operator ùíØ:‚Ñùn‚ÄãN√ó‚Ñùn‚ÄãN‚Üí‚Ñùn‚ÄãN√ó‚Ñùn‚ÄãN:ùíØ‚Üísuperscript‚ÑùùëõùëÅsuperscript‚ÑùùëõùëÅsuperscript‚ÑùùëõùëÅsuperscript‚ÑùùëõùëÅ\mathcal{T}:\mathbb{R}^{nN}\times\mathbb{R}^{nN}\to\mathbb{R}^{nN}\times\mathbb{R}^{nN} characterizing Algorithm¬†1 is contractive. The contraction constant of ùíØùíØ\mathcal{T} is upper bounded by ‚à•S‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•ùëÜ\left\lVert S\right\rVert, and its unique fixed point is [\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚ä§,\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚ä§]‚ä§superscriptsuperscript¬Ø\mathboldùë•topsuperscript¬Ø\mathboldùëßtoptop[\bar{\mathbold{x}}^{\top},\bar{\mathbold{z}}^{\top}]^{\top}, where \mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø¬Ø\mathboldùë•\bar{\mathbold{x}} is the optimal solution to¬†eq.¬†6.

Proof.

1) Fixed point: We start by showing that [\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚ä§,\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚ä§]‚ä§superscriptsuperscript¬Ø\mathboldùë•topsuperscript¬Ø\mathboldùëßtoptop[\bar{\mathbold{x}}^{\top},\bar{\mathbold{z}}^{\top}]^{\top} is indeed a fixed point for ùíØùíØ\mathcal{T}. By Lemma¬†3, the PRS applied to¬†eq.¬†6 is contractive, since f‚àà‚Ñ±Œª¬Ø,Œª¬Ø‚Äã(‚Ñùn‚ÄãN)ùëìsubscript‚Ñ±¬ØùúÜ¬ØùúÜsuperscript‚ÑùùëõùëÅf\in\mathcal{F}_{{\underline{\lambda}},{\bar{\lambda}}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{nN}\right), and its fixed point \mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø¬Ø\mathboldùëß\bar{\mathbold{z}} is such that

Therefore, defining d‚Äã(\mathbold‚Äãx;\mathbold‚Äãz)=f‚Äã(\mathbold‚Äãx)+12‚ÄãœÅ‚Äã‚à•\mathbold‚Äãx‚àí\mathbold‚Äãz‚à•2ùëë\mathboldùë•\mathboldùëßùëì\mathboldùë•12ùúåsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldùë•\mathboldùëß2d(\mathbold{x};\mathbold{z})=f(\mathbold{x})+\frac{1}{2\rho}\left\lVert\mathbold{x}-\mathbold{z}\right\rVert^{2} we have

\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø¬Ø\mathboldùë•\displaystyle\bar{\mathbold{x}} =arg‚Äãmin\mathbold‚Å°x‚Äãd‚Äã(\mathbold‚Äãx;reflœÅ‚Äãg‚Å°(\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø))absentsubscriptargmin\mathboldùë•ùëë\mathboldùë•subscriptreflùúåùëî¬Ø\mathboldùëß\displaystyle=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\mathbold}{x}d(\mathbold{x};\operatorname{refl}_{\rho g}(\bar{\mathbold{z}}))

But this implies that, if we initialize the local updates of Algorithm¬†1 at \mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø,\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø¬Ø\mathboldùë•¬Ø\mathboldùëß\bar{\mathbold{x}},\bar{\mathbold{z}}, then they will return \mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø¬Ø\mathboldùë•\bar{\mathbold{x}} itself, since it is the stationary point of d‚Äã(‚ãÖ;reflœÅ‚Äãg‚Å°(\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø))ùëë‚ãÖsubscriptreflùúåùëî¬Ø\mathboldùëßd(\cdot;\operatorname{refl}_{\rho g}(\bar{\mathbold{z}})). This fact, in addition to the fact that \mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø¬Ø\mathboldùëß\bar{\mathbold{z}} is the fixed point of the PRS¬†eq.¬†8, proves that indeed [\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚ä§,\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚ä§]‚ä§=ùíØ‚Äã[\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚ä§,\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚ä§]‚ä§.superscriptsuperscript¬Ø\mathboldùë•topsuperscript¬Ø\mathboldùëßtoptopùíØsuperscriptsuperscript¬Ø\mathboldùë•topsuperscript¬Ø\mathboldùëßtoptop[\bar{\mathbold{x}}^{\top},\bar{\mathbold{z}}^{\top}]^{\top}=\mathcal{T}[\bar{\mathbold{x}}^{\top},\bar{\mathbold{z}}^{\top}]^{\top}.

2) Contractiveness: We proceed now by proving that ùíØùíØ\mathcal{T} is contractive, and characterizing its contraction rate. We do this by deriving bounds to the distances ‚à•\mathbold‚Äãxk+1‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò1¬Ø\mathboldùë•\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k+1}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert and ‚à•\mathbold‚Äãzk+1‚àí\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò1¬Ø\mathboldùëß\left\lVert\mathbold{z}_{k+1}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\right\rVert.

We start by providing the following auxiliary result. By the discussion above we know that \mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø=arg‚Äãmin\mathbold‚Å°x‚Äãd‚Äã(\mathbold‚Äãx;reflœÅ‚Äãg‚Å°(\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø))¬Ø\mathboldùë•subscriptargmin\mathboldùë•ùëë\mathboldùë•subscriptreflùúåùëî¬Ø\mathboldùëß\bar{\mathbold{x}}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\mathbold}{x}d(\mathbold{x};\operatorname{refl}_{\rho g}(\bar{\mathbold{z}})), and similarly the exact local update¬†eq.¬†8b is given by \mathbold‚Äãx¬Øk+1=arg‚Äãmin\mathbold‚Å°x‚Äãd‚Äã(\mathbold‚Äãx;reflœÅ‚Äãg‚Å°(\mathbold‚Äãzk))subscript¬Ø\mathboldùë•ùëò1subscriptargmin\mathboldùë•ùëë\mathboldùë•subscriptreflùúåùëî\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò\bar{\mathbold{x}}_{k+1}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\mathbold}{x}d(\mathbold{x};\operatorname{refl}_{\rho g}(\mathbold{z}_{k})). But since dùëëd is (Œª¬Ø+1/œÅ)¬ØùúÜ1ùúå({\underline{\lambda}}+1/\rho)-strongly convex in \mathbold‚Äãx\mathboldùë•\mathbold{x}, we can apply the implicit function theorem [44, Theorem¬†1B.1] to prove that

‚à•\mathbold‚Äãx¬Øk+1‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•subscript¬Ø\mathboldùë•ùëò1¬Ø\mathboldùë•\displaystyle\left\lVert\bar{\mathbold{x}}_{k+1}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert ‚â§1Œª¬Ø+1/œÅ‚Äã‚à•reflœÅ‚Äãg‚Å°(\mathbold‚Äãzk)‚àíreflœÅ‚Äãg‚Å°(\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø)‚à•absent1¬ØùúÜ1ùúådelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptreflùúåùëî\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëòsubscriptreflùúåùëî¬Ø\mathboldùëß\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{{\underline{\lambda}}+1/\rho}\left\lVert\operatorname{refl}_{\rho g}(\mathbold{z}_{k})-\operatorname{refl}_{\rho g}(\bar{\mathbold{z}})\right\rVert
‚â§(i)‚Äã1Œª¬Ø+1/œÅ‚Äã‚à•\mathbold‚Äãzk‚àí\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚à•ùëñ1¬ØùúÜ1ùúådelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò¬Ø\mathboldùëß\displaystyle\overset{(i)}{\leq}\frac{1}{{\underline{\lambda}}+1/\rho}\left\lVert\mathbold{z}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\right\rVert (14)

where (i) holds by the fact that the reflective operator is non-expansive [45].

With this result in place, we can now derive the following chain of inequalities:

‚à•\mathbold‚Äãxk+1‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò1¬Ø\mathboldùë•\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k+1}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert ‚â§(i)‚Äã‚à•\mathbold‚Äãxk+1‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Øk+1‚à•+‚à•\mathbold‚Äãx¬Øk+1‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚à•ùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò1subscript¬Ø\mathboldùë•ùëò1delimited-‚à•‚à•subscript¬Ø\mathboldùë•ùëò1¬Ø\mathboldùë•\displaystyle\overset{(i)}{\leq}\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k+1}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}_{k+1}\right\rVert+\left\lVert\bar{\mathbold{x}}_{k+1}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert
‚â§(i‚Äãi)‚Äã‚à•\mathbold‚Äãxk+1‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Øk+1‚à•+1Œª¬Ø+1/œÅ‚Äã‚à•\mathbold‚Äãzk‚àí\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚à•ùëñùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò1subscript¬Ø\mathboldùë•ùëò11¬ØùúÜ1ùúådelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò¬Ø\mathboldùëß\displaystyle\overset{(ii)}{\leq}\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k+1}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}_{k+1}\right\rVert+\frac{1}{{\underline{\lambda}}+1/\rho}\left\lVert\mathbold{z}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\right\rVert
‚â§(i‚Äãi‚Äãi)‚ÄãœáNe‚Äã‚à•\mathbold‚Äãxk‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Øk+1‚à•+1Œª¬Ø+1/œÅ‚Äã‚à•\mathbold‚Äãzk‚àí\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚à•ùëñùëñùëñsuperscriptùúísubscriptùëÅedelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëòsubscript¬Ø\mathboldùë•ùëò11¬ØùúÜ1ùúådelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò¬Ø\mathboldùëß\displaystyle\overset{(iii)}{\leq}\chi^{N_{\mathrm{e}}}\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}_{k+1}\right\rVert+\frac{1}{{\underline{\lambda}}+1/\rho}\left\lVert\mathbold{z}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\right\rVert (15)

where (i) holds by triangle inequality, (ii) by¬†eq.¬†14, and (iii) by contractiveness of the local solvers. By again using the triangle inequality and¬†eq.¬†14 we have

‚à•\mathbold‚Äãxk‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Øk+1‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëòsubscript¬Ø\mathboldùë•ùëò1\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}_{k+1}\right\rVert ‚â§‚à•\mathbold‚Äãxk‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚à•+‚à•\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Øk+1‚à•absentdelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò¬Ø\mathboldùë•delimited-‚à•‚à•¬Ø\mathboldùë•subscript¬Ø\mathboldùë•ùëò1\displaystyle\leq\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert+\left\lVert\bar{\mathbold{x}}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}_{k+1}\right\rVert
‚â§‚à•\mathbold‚Äãxk‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚à•+1Œª¬Ø+1/œÅ‚Äã‚à•\mathbold‚Äãzk‚àí\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚à•,absentdelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò¬Ø\mathboldùë•1¬ØùúÜ1ùúådelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò¬Ø\mathboldùëß\displaystyle\leq\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert+\frac{1}{{\underline{\lambda}}+1/\rho}\left\lVert\mathbold{z}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\right\rVert,

and substituting into¬†eq.¬†15 we get

‚à•\mathbold‚Äãxk+1‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚à•‚â§œáNe‚Äã‚à•\mathbold‚Äãxk‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚à•+1+œáNeŒª¬Ø+1/œÅ‚Äã‚à•\mathbold‚Äãzk‚àí\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚à•.delimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò1¬Ø\mathboldùë•superscriptùúísubscriptùëÅedelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò¬Ø\mathboldùë•1superscriptùúísubscriptùëÅe¬ØùúÜ1ùúådelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò¬Ø\mathboldùëß\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k+1}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert\leq\chi^{N_{\mathrm{e}}}\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert+\frac{1+\chi^{N_{\mathrm{e}}}}{{\underline{\lambda}}+1/\rho}\left\lVert\mathbold{z}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\right\rVert. (16)

We turn now to bounding ‚à•\mathbold‚Äãzk+1‚àí\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò1¬Ø\mathboldùëß\left\lVert\mathbold{z}_{k+1}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\right\rVert. By the updates characterizing Algorithm¬†1 we can write

where recall that \mathbold‚Äãx¬Øk+1subscript¬Ø\mathboldùë•ùëò1\bar{\mathbold{x}}_{k+1} denotes the exact local updates, and ùíØPRsubscriptùíØPR\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{PR}} denotes the exact PRS.

We can then derive the following bound:

‚â§(i‚Äãi)‚ÄãŒ∂‚Äã‚à•\mathbold‚Äãzk‚àí\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚à•+2‚Äã‚à•\mathbold‚Äãxk+1‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Øk+1‚à•ùëñùëñùúÅdelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò¬Ø\mathboldùëß2delimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò1subscript¬Ø\mathboldùë•ùëò1\displaystyle\qquad\overset{(ii)}{\leq}\zeta\left\lVert\mathbold{z}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\right\rVert+2\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k+1}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}_{k+1}\right\rVert

where (i) holds by triangle inequality, (ii) by the PRS operator ùíØPRsubscriptùíØPR\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{PR}} being contractive by Lemma¬†3, and (iii) by an argument similar to that leading to¬†eq.¬†16 and rearranging.

Finally, putting¬†eqs.¬†16 and¬†17 together yields

[‚à•\mathbold‚Äãxk+1‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚à•‚à•\mathbold‚Äãzk+1‚àí\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚à•]‚â§S‚Äã[‚à•\mathbold‚Äãxk‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚à•‚à•\mathbold‚Äãzk‚àí\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚à•]matrixdelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò1¬Ø\mathboldùë•delimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò1¬Ø\mathboldùëßùëÜmatrixdelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò¬Ø\mathboldùë•delimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò¬Ø\mathboldùëß\begin{bmatrix}\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k+1}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert\\ \left\lVert\mathbold{z}_{k+1}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\right\rVert\end{bmatrix}\leq S\begin{bmatrix}\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert\\ \left\lVert\mathbold{z}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\right\rVert\end{bmatrix}

and taking the square norm on both sides

‚à•\mathbold‚Äãxk+1‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚à•2+‚à•\mathbold‚Äãzk+1‚àí\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚à•2‚â§‚à•S‚Äã[‚à•\mathbold‚Äãxk‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚à•‚à•\mathbold‚Äãzk‚àí\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚à•]‚à•2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò1¬Ø\mathboldùë•2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò1¬Ø\mathboldùëß2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëÜmatrixdelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò¬Ø\mathboldùë•delimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò¬Ø\mathboldùëß2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k+1}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert^{2}+\left\lVert\mathbold{z}_{k+1}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\right\rVert^{2}\leq\left\lVert S\begin{bmatrix}\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert\\ \left\lVert\mathbold{z}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\right\rVert\end{bmatrix}\right\rVert^{2}
‚â§‚à•S‚à•2‚Äã(‚à•\mathbold‚Äãxk‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚à•2+‚à•\mathbold‚Äãzk‚àí\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚à•2).absentsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëÜ2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò¬Ø\mathboldùë•2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò¬Ø\mathboldùëß2\displaystyle\qquad\leq\left\lVert S\right\rVert^{2}\left(\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert^{2}+\left\lVert\mathbold{z}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\right\rVert^{2}\right).

Therefore by Definition¬†2 this proves that Algorithm¬†1 is indeed contractive. ‚àé

Remark 2 (The importance of initialization).

Initializing the local update computation¬†eq.¬†11 with wi,k0=xi,ksuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëñùëò0subscriptùë•ùëñùëòw_{i,k}^{0}=x_{i,k} is fundamental to guarantee contractiveness of Algorithm¬†1, and thus its convergence, as detailed in the following section¬†V-B.

V-B Convergence results

Proposition¬†1 proved that Algorithm¬†1 can be modeled as a contractive operator when all the agents are active. This fact then would allow us to characterize the convergence of the algorithm by using Banach-Picard theorem (cf. Lemma¬†1). However, in this section we are interested in analyzing convergence with partial participation, that is, when only a (random) subset of agents is active at each time k‚àà‚Ñïùëò‚Ñïk\in\mathbb{N}. In addition to partial participation, we are interested in convergence when a further source of stochasticity is present: inexact local solvers. In section¬†IV-B we have indeed discussed two local solvers that, either due to computational constraints or privacy concerns, introduce inexactness during training.

To account for both partial participation and inexact local training, we can write Algorithm¬†1 as the following stochastic update

[xi,k+1zi,k+1]={[ùí≥i‚Äã(xi,k,\mathbold‚Äãzk)zi,k+2‚Äã(ùí≥i‚Äã(xi,k,\mathbold‚Äãzk)‚àíyk+1)]+ei,kif‚Äãui,k=1[xi,kzi,k]if‚Äãui,k=0matrixsubscriptùë•ùëñùëò1subscriptùëßùëñùëò1casesmatrixsubscriptùí≥ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùëò\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëòsubscriptùëßùëñùëò2subscriptùí≥ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùëò\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëò1subscriptùëíùëñùëòotherwiseifsubscriptùë¢ùëñùëò1otherwisematrixsubscriptùë•ùëñùëòsubscriptùëßùëñùëòifsubscriptùë¢ùëñùëò0otherwise\begin{bmatrix}x_{i,k+1}\\ z_{i,k+1}\end{bmatrix}=\begin{cases}\begin{bmatrix}\mathcal{X}_{i}(x_{i,k},\mathbold{z}_{k})\\ z_{i,k}+2(\mathcal{X}_{i}(x_{i,k},\mathbold{z}_{k})-y_{k+1})\end{bmatrix}+e_{i,k}\\ \hskip 142.26378pt\text{if}\ u_{i,k}=1\\ \begin{bmatrix}x_{i,k}\\ z_{i,k}\end{bmatrix}\hskip 113.81102pt\text{if}\ u_{i,k}=0\end{cases} (18)

Proposition 2 (Convergence).

Let the parameters of Algorithm¬†1 be such that Proposition¬†1 holds, and let Assumption¬†2 be verified. Proof.

If Proposition¬†1 is verified, then the algorithm is contractive, and under Assumption¬†2 we can apply the stochastic Banach-Picard of Lemma¬†4. ‚àé

Proposition¬†2 proves that, for a suitable choice of parameters, Algorithm¬†1 converges when the agents apply (stochastic) gradient descent during local training. The following result shows that convergence is achieved also when the agents employ the accelerated gradient descent as a local solver.

where

Remark 3 (Exact convergence).

Notice that when exact local solvers are employed (hence ŒΩ=0ùúà0\nu=0 in Assumption¬†2) then Propositions¬†2 and¬†3 prove exact convergence to the fixed point [\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø‚ä§‚Äã\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø‚ä§]‚ä§superscriptdelimited-[]superscript¬Ø\mathboldùë•topsuperscript¬Ø\mathboldùëßtoptop[\bar{\mathbold{x}}^{\top}\ \bar{\mathbold{z}}^{\top}]^{\top}, even in the presence of partial participation. As a consequence, the proposed algorithm indeed allows for the use of local training without degrading accuracy (objective (i) in section¬†III-B).

VI Privacy Analysis

In this section, we prove that Algorithm¬†1, utilizing the noisy gradient descent¬†eq.¬†13 as local training method, guarantees RDP for every data sample in ùíü:=‚à™i=1Nùíüiassignùíüsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsubscriptùíüùëñ\mathcal{D}:=\cup_{i=1}^{N}\mathcal{D}_{i}. We will derive this result in the case of full agents‚Äô participation, which can provide an upper bound to the privacy guarantee with partial participation. Before proceeding to the analysis, we make the following assumption.

Assumption 3 (Sensitivity).

For each i‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,N}ùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅi\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, there exists some L>0ùêø0L>0 such that

‚à•‚àáfiùíüi‚Äã(x)‚àí‚àáfiùíüi‚Ä≤‚Äã(x)‚à•‚â§Lq,‚àÄx‚àà‚Ñùnformulae-sequencedelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùíüùëñùë•‚àásuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùíü‚Ä≤ùëñùë•ùêøùëûfor-allùë•superscript‚Ñùùëõ\left\lVert\nabla f_{i}^{\mathcal{D}_{i}}(x)-\nabla f_{i}^{\mathcal{D}^{\prime}_{i}}(x)\right\rVert\leq\frac{L}{q},\quad\forall x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}

where ‚àáfiùíüi‚àásuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùíüùëñ\nabla f_{i}^{\mathcal{D}_{i}} denotes the gradient of fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i} induced by the dataset ùíüisubscriptùíüùëñ\mathcal{D}_{i}, and ùíüisubscriptùíüùëñ\mathcal{D}_{i} and ùíüi‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùíü‚Ä≤ùëñ\mathcal{D}^{\prime}_{i} are neighboring datasets of size qùëûq.

Assumption¬†3 quantifies the sensitivity of local gradient queries, which is a well-established concept in the field of machine learning with differential privacy [20, 42]. It is commonly satisfied in various learning problems, such as those involving l2subscriptùëô2l_{2} regularized logistic loss (where the regularization ensures that Assumption¬†1 is also satisfied). For more general loss functions, the use of clipped gradients during training guarantees that Assumption¬†3 is verified [46]. Specifically, the gradients are clipped using the expression ‚àá‚Ñìi‚Äã(xi;Œæi(j))‚ãÖmin‚Å°{1,L2‚Äã‚à•‚àá‚Ñìi‚Äã(xi;Œæi(j))‚à•}‚ãÖ‚àásubscript‚Ñìùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúâùëñùëó1ùêø2delimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásubscript‚Ñìùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúâùëñùëó\nabla\ell_{i}(x_{i};\xi_{i}^{(j)})\cdot\min\left\{1,\frac{L}{2\lVert\nabla\ell_{i}(x_{i};\xi_{i}^{(j)})\rVert}\right\}, where Œæi(j)‚ààùíüisuperscriptsubscriptùúâùëñùëósubscriptùíüùëñ\xi_{i}^{(j)}\in\mathcal{D}_{i}.

We are now ready to provide our privacy guarantee.

Proposition 4 (Privacy).

Suppose Assumptions¬†1 and¬†3 hold. Let the agents employ the noisy gradient descent¬†eq.¬†13 with noise variance œÑ2<‚àûsuperscriptùúè2\tau^{2}<\infty as local solver. If the step-size Œ≥<2/(Œª¬Ø+œÅ‚àí1)ùõæ2¬ØùúÜsuperscriptùúå1\gamma<2/({\bar{\lambda}}+\rho^{-1}) and each xi,0subscriptùë•ùëñ0x_{i,0} is drawn from ùí©‚Äã(0,2‚ÄãœÑ2‚ÄãIn/Œª¬Ø)ùí©02superscriptùúè2subscriptùêºùëõ¬ØùúÜ\mathcal{N}(0,2\tau^{2}I_{n}/{\underline{\lambda}}), then Algorithm¬†1 satisfies (Œª,Œµ)ùúÜùúÄ(\lambda,\varepsilon)-R√©nyi differential privacy with

Œµ‚â§Œª‚ÄãL2Œª¬Ø‚ÄãœÑ2‚Äãq2‚Äã(1‚àíe‚àíŒª¬Ø‚ÄãŒ≥‚ÄãK‚ÄãNe/2)ùúÄùúÜsuperscriptùêø2¬ØùúÜsuperscriptùúè2superscriptùëû21superscriptùëí¬ØùúÜùõæùêæsubscriptùëÅe2\varepsilon\leq\frac{\lambda L^{2}}{{\underline{\lambda}}\tau^{2}q^{2}}\left(1-e^{-{\underline{\lambda}}\gamma K{N_{\mathrm{e}}}/2}\right)

where qùëûq is the number of local samples, Œª¬Ø¬ØùúÜ{\underline{\lambda}} and Œª¬Ø¬ØùúÜ{\bar{\lambda}} are the strong convexity modulus and smoothness parameter of the local cost, respectively.

Proof.

‚àé

By applying Lemma¬†5, we can convert the RDP guarantee presented in Proposition¬†4 into an (Œµ,Œ¥)ùúÄùõø(\varepsilon,\delta)-ADP guarantee, where ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon is given by the following expression:

Œµ=Œª‚ÄãL2Œª¬Ø‚ÄãœÑ2‚Äãq2‚Äã(1‚àíe‚àíŒª¬Ø‚ÄãŒ≥‚ÄãK‚ÄãNe/2)+log‚Å°(1/Œ¥)Œª‚àí1,‚àÄŒ¥‚àà(0,1).formulae-sequenceùúÄùúÜsuperscriptùêø2¬ØùúÜsuperscriptùúè2superscriptùëû21superscriptùëí¬ØùúÜùõæùêæsubscriptùëÅe21ùõøùúÜ1for-allùõø01\varepsilon=\frac{\lambda L^{2}}{{\underline{\lambda}}\tau^{2}q^{2}}\left(1-e^{-{\underline{\lambda}}\gamma K{N_{\mathrm{e}}}/2}\right)+\frac{\log(1/\delta)}{\lambda-1},\quad\forall\delta\in(0,1).

This result reveals that the privacy loss of Algorithm¬†1 grows as the number of iterations increases, eventually reaching a constant upper bound. This characterization is based on the dynamics analysis of RDP loss in [20], and is arguably tighter than previous approaches based on advanced composition of differential privacy [48], privacy amplification by iteration [49], and privacy amplification by subsampling [12, 40] (cf. the discussion in [20]).

The use of noisy gradient descent as a privacy preserving mechanism of course has an impact on the accuracy of Algorithm¬†1. The following result quantifies the inexact convergence of the algorithm for a given privacy threshold.

Corollary 1 (Accuracy).

Consider Algorithm¬†1 with noisy gradient descent¬†eq.¬†13 as local training method, with noise variance œÑ2<‚àûsuperscriptùúè2\tau^{2}<\infty and step-size Œ≥<2/(Œª¬Ø+œÅ‚àí1)ùõæ2¬ØùúÜsuperscriptùúå1\gamma<2/({\bar{\lambda}}+\rho^{-1}). Suppose that each xi,0subscriptùë•ùëñ0x_{i,0} is drawn from ùí©‚Äã(0,2‚ÄãœÑ2‚ÄãIn/Œª¬Ø)ùí©02superscriptùúè2subscriptùêºùëõ¬ØùúÜ\mathcal{N}(0,2\tau^{2}I_{n}/{\underline{\lambda}}), and that Assumptions¬†1 and¬†2 hold. Then at time K‚àà‚Ñïùêæ‚ÑïK\in\mathbb{N} we have

ùîº‚Äã[‚à•[\mathbold‚ÄãxK‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø\mathbold‚ÄãzK‚àí\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø]‚à•]ùîºdelimited-[]delimited-‚à•‚à•matrix\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùêæ¬Ø\mathboldùë•\mathboldsubscriptùëßùêæ¬Ø\mathboldùëß\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\begin{bmatrix}\mathbold{x}_{K}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\\ \mathbold{z}_{K}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\end{bmatrix}\right\rVert\right] ‚â§‚à•S‚à•K‚Äã‚à•[\mathbold‚Äãx0‚àí\mathbold‚Äãx¬Ø\mathbold‚Äãz0‚àí\mathbold‚Äãz¬Ø]‚à•+absentlimit-fromsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëÜùêædelimited-‚à•‚à•matrix\mathboldsubscriptùë•0¬Ø\mathboldùë•\mathboldsubscriptùëß0¬Ø\mathboldùëß\displaystyle\leq\left\lVert S\right\rVert^{K}\left\lVert\begin{bmatrix}\mathbold{x}_{0}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\\ \mathbold{z}_{0}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\end{bmatrix}\right\rVert+
+1‚àí‚à•S‚à•K1‚àí‚à•S‚à•‚ÄãœÑ‚Äã10‚Äãn‚ÄãN‚ÄãŒ≥‚Äã1‚àíœáNe1‚àíœá1superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëÜùêæ1delimited-‚à•‚à•ùëÜùúè10ùëõùëÅùõæ1superscriptùúísubscriptùëÅe1ùúí\displaystyle+\frac{1-\left\lVert S\right\rVert^{K}}{1-\left\lVert S\right\rVert}\tau\sqrt{10nN\gamma}\frac{1-\chi^{N_{\mathrm{e}}}}{1-\chi}

Proof.

The result follows as a consequence of Proposition¬†2 by showing that Algorithm¬†1 with noisy gradient descent as local training method can be written as¬†eq.¬†18. Denote by ùí≥‚Äã(\mathbold‚Äãxk,\mathbold‚Äãzk)ùí≥\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò\mathcal{X}(\mathbold{x}_{k},\mathbold{z}_{k}) and ùí≥^‚Äã(\mathbold‚Äãxk,\mathbold‚Äãzk)^ùí≥\mathboldsubscriptùë•ùëò\mathboldsubscriptùëßùëò\hat{\mathcal{X}}(\mathbold{x}_{k},\mathbold{z}_{k}) the output of the local training step when gradient, respectively noisy gradient, is used. Then we can characterize Algorithm¬†1 by the following update

Therefore, the larger the noise variance œÑ2superscriptùúè2\tau^{2} is, the less accurate the algorithm becomes. This captures the well-known trade-off between guaranteeing privacy and achieving accuracy [10, 21].

VII Numerical Results

In this section we evaluate the performance of the proposed Fed-PLT, and compare it with the alternative algorithms discussed in section¬†I-A. We consider a logistic regression problem characterized by the local loss functions

fi‚Äã(x)=1mi‚Äã‚àëh=1milog‚Å°(1+exp‚Å°(‚àíbi,h‚Äãai,h‚Äãx))+œµ2‚ÄãN‚Äã‚à•x‚à•2subscriptùëìùëñùë•1subscriptùëöùëñsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñé1subscriptùëöùëñ1subscriptùëèùëñ‚Ñésubscriptùëéùëñ‚Ñéùë•italic-œµ2ùëÅsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùë•2f_{i}(x)=\frac{1}{m_{i}}\sum_{h=1}^{m_{i}}\log\left(1+\exp\left(-b_{i,h}a_{i,h}x\right)\right)+\frac{\epsilon}{2N}\left\lVert x\right\rVert^{2}

The simulations are implemented in Python building on top of the tvopt library [51]. All the results involving randomness are averaged over 100100100 Monte Carlo iterations.

VII-A Comparison with different solvers and partial participation

We start by comparing the proposed Fed-PLT with the alternative algorithms discussed in section¬†I-A: Fed-PD [29], FedLin [30], TAMUNA [31], LED [32], and 5GCS [14]. For all algorithms except TAMUNA [31], we set the number of local training epochs to Ne=10subscriptùëÅe10{N_{\mathrm{e}}}=10; for TAMUNA, the number of local epochs at time kùëòk is drawn from a random geometric distribution with mean equals to NesubscriptùëÅe{N_{\mathrm{e}}}. The other parameters of the algorithms (e.g. step-size of the local solvers) are tuned to achieve the best performance possible.

In Table¬†II we compare the algorithms in terms of convergence rate when using two different local solvers, gradient descent and accelerated gradient descent. Notice that, except for Fed-PLT and 5GCS, no convergence guarantee is provided when the accelerated gradient is used. Additionally, for the algorithms that allow it, we also compare the performance with full participation (all agents are active at all time kùëòk) and with partial participation (only N/2ùëÅ2N/2 agents are active). In the case of partial participation, the active agents are selected uniformly at random.

As we can see from Table¬†II, Fed-PLT achieves the best convergence rate in all scenarios. Notice that Fed-PD, FedLin, TAMUNA, LED are not designed to use accelerated gradient, but a straightforward modification allows for it. And interestingly, they do achieve convergence, even though there are no theoretical guarantees of it. Another observation is that the convergence rate increases when partial participation is applied. This is in line with previous results on decentralized optimization [52]. Finally, it is interesting to notice that the use of gradient descent as local solver yields often lower convergence rates than accelerated gradient descent. A possible explanation is that the overall convergence is not dominated by the convergence rate of the local solver. For example in the case of Fed-PLT, the convergence may be dominated by Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta, the convergence rate of the exact PRS (cf. Proposition¬†1).

We further analyze the performance of Fed-PLT with partial participation. In Table¬†III we report the empirical convergence rate computed for different numbers of participating agents, up to full participation of the NùëÅN agents. As observed above, the fewer agents participate at each iteration, the higher the convergence rate.

We conclude this section by studying the performance of Fed-PLT when the privacy-preserving noisy gradient descent is used as a local solver. As discussed in section¬†VI, the use of such solver results in a decrease in accuracy of the learned model, with the asymptotic error being bounded by a non-zero value (cf. Corollary¬†1). In Table¬†IV we report the empirical value of such asymptotic error when different values of the noise variance œÑùúè\tau are used. As foreseen by Corollary¬†1, the larger the variance is the larger the asymptotic error.

VII-B Tuning the parameters of Fed-PLT

The results of the previous section were obtained by setting Ne=10subscriptùëÅe10{N_{\mathrm{e}}}=10 in Fed-PLT, and tuning its parameter œÅùúå\rho to achieve an optimal convergence rate. In this section we further characterize the effect of both œÅùúå\rho and NesubscriptùëÅe{N_{\mathrm{e}}} on Fed-PLT‚Äôs convergence.

We start by showing in Figure¬†2 the empirical convergence rate when Ne=10subscriptùëÅe10{N_{\mathrm{e}}}=10 and œÅùúå\rho ranges between 10‚àí3superscript10310^{-3} and 103superscript10310^{3}. As we can see, the rate is optimized for a value of œÅ‚âà0.3ùúå0.3\rho\approx 0.3 and grows larger for extreme values in both directions. The rate thus resembles that of the exact PRS from which Fed-PLT is derived, see e.g. [53, Figures¬†1,¬†2].

In Figure¬†3 we plot the rate obtained setting œÅ=0.3ùúå0.3\rho=0.3 and varying the number of local epochs NesubscriptùëÅe{N_{\mathrm{e}}} from 111 to 505050. Interestingly, the rate is not a monotonically decreasing function of NesubscriptùëÅe{N_{\mathrm{e}}}. Rather, the rate decreases to a minimum for Ne‚âà10subscriptùëÅe10{N_{\mathrm{e}}}\approx 10, and then increases again, settling on a constant value for Ne>20subscriptùëÅe20{N_{\mathrm{e}}}>20. Further simulations show that such rate is constant for all values Ne>20subscriptùëÅe20{N_{\mathrm{e}}}>20 and very close to the rate Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta of the exact PRS (where Ne‚Üí‚àû‚ÜísubscriptùëÅe{N_{\mathrm{e}}}\to\infty). Therefore, it appears that the use of an inexact proximal computation during local training can improve the speed of convergence. Quantifying this speed-up from a theoretical perspective is an interesting direction for future research.

We conclude by remarking that these results lend further credence to the fact that the convergence rate of Fed-PLT is dominated by Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta rather than by the local training solver. Indeed, as observed Figure¬†2 resembles the rate of the exact PRS, and in Figure¬†3 the rate is very close to Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta even for small values of Ne‚âà20subscriptùëÅe20{N_{\mathrm{e}}}\approx 20.

Lemma 7 (Contraction of accelerated gradient).

Let f‚àà‚Ñ±Œª¬Ø,Œª¬Ø‚Äã(‚Ñùn)ùëìsubscript‚Ñ±¬ØùúÜ¬ØùúÜsuperscript‚Ñùùëõf\in\mathcal{F}_{{\underline{\lambda}},{\bar{\lambda}}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right), then the accelerated gradient descent

is a sufficient condition for the accelerated gradient to be contractive.
